questions.text: What is the most important factor influencing the focus of light rays on the retina?
questions.solution:
The anterior surface of the cornea is the most important factor influencing the focus of light rays on the retina.

The refraction of light is the maximum at the cornea, due to the curvature of the cornea and the difference between the refractive index of air and tear film.

questions.text: The refractive index is the maximum at the ____________.
questions.solution:
The refractive index is the maximum at the center of the lens.

The total dioptric power of the lens is about 18 D (16 to 20 D). Lens is composed of 64% water, 35% protein, and 1% lipid/carbohydrates/trace elements, and these components contribute to the refractive index of the lens.

questions.text: How many Purkinje images are formed in a normal eye?
questions.solution:
A total of 4 Purkinje images are formed in normal eyes.

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images.

Image  Location Direction
Image 1 Anterior surface of the cornea Erect
Image 2 Posterior surface of the cornea Erect
Image 3 Anterior surface of the lens Erect
Image 4 Posterior surface of the lens Inverted

 

In aphakia, images 3 and 4 are absent, while in a mature cataract, image 4 is absent.

questions.text: Among the Purkinje images in the eye, which image is inverted?
questions.solution: Image 4, which is formed on the posterior surface of the lens, is inverted.

questions.text: The visual axis is the line joining the _________.

choices.text: Centre of the cornea to the retina
Centre of the lens to the cornea

questions.solution:
The visual axis is the line joining the fixation point (object), nodal point (centre of the lens), and the fovea.

Fixation Axis   Line joining the fixation point (object) and the centre of rotation

questions.text: What is the angle formed between the optic axis and visual axis at the nodal point?
questions.solution:
Angle alpha (α) is the angle between the optical axis and visual axis at the nodal point. 

Angle lambda (λ) is the angle between the pupillary axis and the line of sight.  It is the global tilt offset of the eye when it fixates on a specific target and is a response to the eccentric displaced position of the fovea from the geometrical center of the retina. (Option B)

Angle kappa (κ) is the angle between the visual axis and the pupillary line at the cornea. It is the only angle that can be measured and is of clinical significance. (Option C)

  • Positive κ is seen in pseudoexotropia
  • Negative κ is seen in pseudoesotropia

Angle gamma (γ) is the angle between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the center of eyeball rotation. (Option D)

  Visual axis Line of sight Fixation axis
Pupillary axis Kappa (κ) Lambda (λ)  
Optic Axis Alpha (α)   Gamma (γ)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to get his power checked. The optometrist finds the focal length of his lens to be 0.75m; what will be its refractive power?
questions.solution:
Refractive power (dioptre) =  1/Focal length in metres

So, for the given question, refractive power (D) = 1/0.75 = 1.33 D

questions.text:
What is the distance between point A and B shown below?

DD - Disc Diameter
questions.solution:
In the image, point A is the optic disc and point B is the fovea. The fovea is situated about 2 disc diameters (3–4 mm) away from the temporal margin of the optic disc.

The optic disc is an area of about 1.5 mm. There is a blind spot / physiological scotoma, corresponding to the optic disc.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child complains that she cannot see anything on the whiteboard clearly.  On ophthalmological examination, she is found to have a 2 mm shortening of the axial length of the eyeball. How much eye power will this lead to?
questions.solution:
Shortening of 2mm of the axial length of the eyeball will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.

In axial hypermetropia, 1mm shortening of the anteroposterior diameter of the eye results in 3 dioptres of hypermetropia. Therefore, 2-mm shortening will lead to 6D of hypermetropia.

In curvature hypermetropia, a 1mm increase in radius of curvature results in 6 dioptres of hypermetropia.

questions.text: You are studying the optics of a patient with regular astigmatism. Identify the point at which the clearest image is formed?
questions.solution:
The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least confusion. 

When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical and horizontal rays converge at different points.

The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval.

For the given Sturm's conoid, 

  • At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than horizontal rays.
  • At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a horizontal straight line.
  • At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging.
  • At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion.
  • At point E, a vertical oval is formed.
  • At point F, a vertical straight line is formed
  • At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

questions.text: What is the Stiles-Crawford effect?

choices.text: Cutting off of the peripheral rays by the iris
High refractive index of the core of nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
More sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays

questions.solution:
The Stiles–Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays. It is one of the natural mechanisms that decrease aberration in the eye. The rays of light that enter through the center of the pupil have higher sensitivity as compared to those entering from the periphery of the pupil.  

Natural mechanisms that decrease aberrations in the human eye:

  • Cutting-off of the peripheral rays by the iris
  • The high refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
  • Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
  • Stiles–Crawford effect

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Rods and cones release Ach at their synapses.
Bipolar cells show either depolarization or hyperpolarization.

questions.solution:
Rods and cones release glutamate (not acetylcholine) at their synapses.

Photoreceptors get hyperpolarized in response to stimulus, and hence, phototransduction is associated with hyperpolarization.

Amacrine cells secrete at least eight types of neurotransmitters, including GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine, and indolamine, all of which function as inhibitory neurotransmitters.

Bipolar cells show both depolarization/hyperpolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for inducing phototransduction?
questions.solution:
Metarhodopsin II is responsible for phototransduction.

It activates transducin member of G proteins. This leads to the closure of Na+ channels and hyperpolarization, thereby inducing phototransduction (signal transduction in the retina).

questions.text: During the dark phase of the visual cycle, which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to form rhodopsin?
questions.solution:
Opsin combines with 11-cis-retinal to produce rhodopsin.

Only the retinal form of vitamin A is involved in the formation of the photopigment.

 

The common food sources of preformed vitamin A (retinol) are liver, kidney, egg yolk, and butter. Provitamin A (beta-carotene) is mostly found in green leafy vegetables, sweet potatoes, and carrots. Because vitamin A from animal sources or supplements is preformed, it is more likely to cause toxicity than the provitamin A from plant sources.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the physiology of photoreceptors?

choices.text: Phototransduction results in closure of c-GMP-gated cation channels.
Chromophore regeneration occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors.
Photon absorption induces photo-isomerisation of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal.
11-cis-Retinal is bound to opsins by covalent bonds.

questions.solution:
Chromophore regeneration occurs in the retinal pigment epithelial cells.

Phototransduction:

  • Rhodopsin is a G-protein-coupled receptor found in the outer segments of rod photoreceptors.
  • 11-cis-retinal (a chromophore) is covalently bound to opsins via a lysine residue on one of the transmembrane domains.
  • The receptor is activated by photo-isomerization of prebound 11-cis-retinal to ALL-TRANS-retinal.
  • Activation of the receptor causes binding and activation of the G protein, transducin, with signal transduction via cGMP phosphodiesterase, resulting in a decrease in the intracellular cGMP levels and closure of the cGMP-gated Na channels.
  • This causes hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell, which modulates neurotransmitter release at the synapse with bipolar cells.
  • This entire process triggered by the activation of rhodopsin is phototransduction, which occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors and converts light energy into an electrical signal.

Chromophore regeneration:

  • All-trans retinAL is converted to all-trans-retinOL.
  • All-trans-retinOL gets transported by interphotoreceptor retinoid-binding protein (IRBP) to the retinal pigment epithelial cells, where it is reconstituted into the 11-cis retinal isoform.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding "blobs" in the primary visual cortex?

choices.text: Are rich in the enzyme citrate synthase
Are present in layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex
Receive input from the interlaminar pathway

questions.solution:
Blobs in the primary visual cortex are rich in the enzyme cytochrome oxidase.

Blobs are sections of the visual cortex where groups of neurons that are sensitive to color assemble in cylindrical shapes. They are present in layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex.

questions.text: What are Konio cells involved in transmitting?
questions.solution:
Konio cells are involved in the transmission of color.

Lateral geniculate Striate cortex Extra-striate cortex Higher centers for body
Magno cells → → Motion and stereo
Parvo cells → → Form
Konio cells → → Color

The koniocellular pathway is ventral to each parvocellular and magnocellular layer of the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN). K cells are neurochemically and anatomically distinct from M and P cells. They contain calbindin protein, whereas M cells and P cells contain parvalbumin. K1, K4, and K6 receive ipsilateral retinal inputs, and K3 and K5 receive contralateral retinal inputs. K2 receives both.

questions.text: What is the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum of the human eye?
questions.solution:
The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm.

Theories of color vision: 

  • Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different spectral sensitivities.
  • Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green).
  • Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture.

questions.text: What is the characteristic visual defect in deuteranomaly?
questions.solution:
In deuteranomaly, the perception of green color is defective. It is the most common disorder of color vision.

Monochromacy: Only one of the three primary colors (red, blue, or green) can be appreciated.

Dichromacy: Two primary colors are appreciated. (anopia = absent).

  • Protanopia: Red color is not perceived.
  • Deuteranopia: Green color is not perceived.
  • Tritanopia: Blue color is not perceived.

Trichromacy: All the three primary colors are appreciated, but one of them can be defective (anomaly = defective).

  • Protanomaly: Red color perception is defective.
  • Deuteranomaly: Green color perception is defective.
  • Tritanomaly: Blue color perception is defective.

Achromatopsia: No color perception due to the absence of cones. It may also occur in the lesion of area V4 or V8 of the visual cortex.

questions.text: Majority of the energy requirement in the lens is met by the ______________.
questions.solution:
Majority of the energy requirement of the lens is met by glycolysis. 

90–95 % of the glucose that enters the lens is converted to glucose 6 phosphate by hexokinase. The remaining 5% is converted to sorbitol and gluconic acid.

The glucose-6-phosphate formed is metabolized in 3 ways: 

  • Glycolysis: 80 %
  • Pentose phosphate pathway: 10%
  • TCA cycle: 3%

Energy in the lens is stored in the form of ATP.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the optotype on the second line of Snellen’s chart when viewed from a distance of 6 meters?
questions.solution:
The angle subtended by the optotype (individual letters on the chart) on the second line of Snellen’s chart in the above case would be 30 minutes of arc.

The second line on Snellen’s chart corresponds to a distance of 36 meters. When viewed from a 6m distance, it is denoted as visual acuity 6/36. Where,

  • The numerator (6) denotes the distance from which the patient is actually viewing it
  • The denominator (36) denotes the distance at which it should be ideally viewed. It denotes the distance at which each stroke of the letter would subtend the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of one minute of arc.

MAR = 1/Visual acuity

Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of individual limbs of the letters. Hence, the angle subtended by the optotype= MAR x 5

For eg: At exactly 6 meters distance from the patient, the letters on the 6/6 line shall subtend 5 minutes of arc (such that the individual limbs of the letters subtend 1 minute of arc).

The equation to calculate the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is given as follows:

For the given question,

MAR = 1/ 6/36
MAR = 36/6
MAR = 6 minutes of arc

Hence, the angle subtended by the entire letter is 6 × 5 = 30 minutes of arc.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with monocular aphakia wears contact lenses. What is the approximate percentage of aniseikonia in his eyes?
questions.solution:
The approximate percentage of aniseikonia in a person with monocular aphakia wearing a contact lens would be 8%.

Aniseikonia is defined as the difference in image size between the two eyes and can lead to disturbances in stereopsis. The tolerable limit of aniseikonia is 5–8%. It is reduced with contact lens (8%) compared to glasses (25–30%) in aphakia.

However, the percentage of aniseikonia is least with an intraocular lens (IOL) (1–3%), thus secondary IOL implantation is the most preferred management of unilateral aphakia.

questions.text: Which cerebellar nucleus controls the ocular saccade?
questions.solution:
The Floccular nucleus of the cerebellum controls ocular saccades.

A saccade is a rapid ballistic movement to change the point of fixation. It is the fastest of all eye movements and is initiated by the contralateral frontal lobe. Smooth pursuit is a slow tracking movement to keep the target on the fovea. It is controlled by the ipsilateral parieto-occipital lobe. 

Following an object from the right to left is left pursuit and is controlled by ipsilateral (left) parieto-occipital lobe, and the corrective movement is a saccade (in this case, left to right) termed right saccade and is controlled by the contralateral (left) frontal lobe.

The floccular nucleus is found in the lobule HX of the cerebellar vermis. Its functions include matching pulse-step, gaze holding, and sustained smooth pursuit. Bilateral lesions of the flocculus result in the following:

  • Post-saccadic drift- saccadic movements do not stop, but there is a brief, several hundred milliseconds drift of the eyes after each saccade.
  • Saccadic pursuit- smooth tracking is replaced by simultaneous rapid jerking motions of the eye to follow an object toward the ipsilateral visual field.
  • Gaze-evoked nystagmus- impaired ability to hold the eyes in the eccentric position, resulting in gaze-evoked nystagmus towards the affected side of the cerebellum.

Emboliform and globose nuclei: Generation of vertical saccades

Fastigial nuclei: Pursuit initiation

questions.text: Purely depolarizing cells in the optic pathway are ________.
questions.solution: Amacrine cells are the cells that produce purely depolarizing potential and spikes.

questions.text: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body terminate in the primary visual cortex in ______.
questions.solution:
Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) terminate in the primary visual cortex in layer 4.

Both the magnocellular and parvocellular pathways from the LGB terminate in layer 4 of the visual cortex. Only the interlaminar pathway terminates in layers 2 and 3.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What is the mean value for outflow facility of the aqueous in the normal eye?
questions.solution:
The aqueous outflow facility is about 0.28 µL/min/mmHg. Aqueous humor is produced at an average rate of 2.0–2.5 µL/min.

The ease with which the aqueous humor leaves the eye is called an aqueous outflow facility.

  • The outflow facility is measured using tonography.
  • The normal range is between 0.22–0.28 µL/min/mmHg.
  • A juxtacanalicular portion of the trabecular meshwork is the primary limiting factor for the outflow facility.
  • Uveoscleral outflow accounts for 10% of the total aqueous outflow facility.
  • Aqueous outflow facility decreases with aging.
  • Trabecular outflow facility is reduced in glaucoma.
  • Laser trabeculoplasty reduces intraocular pressure (IOP) in open-angle glaucoma by increasing the trabecular outflow facility.
